title: Israel's war in Gaza has already proved particularly devastating for children
summary: By mid-March, the UN announced that more children had been killed in the Palestinian enclave since October 2023 than in four years of conflict worldwide.

title: Visualizing the large scale destruction of Gaza's hospitals, schools and places of worship
summary: Thanks to open-source and UN data, Le Monde was able to establish that 60% of schools, hospitals and places of worship have been completely destroyed or damaged in Gaza since October 7, 2023.

title: Xi Jinping's new economic model promises more trade conflicts for China
summary: Electric cars, batteries and solar panels are often cited as an example of China's economic model, along with semi-conductors, biotechnologies and the digital economy.

title: Israel says it was targeting 'Hamas gunman' in airstrike that killed seven aid workers
summary: Two Israeli army officers who ordered a strike on a humanitarian convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers have been fired. WCK is demanding an independent investigation.

title: The effects of cleaning products on housekeeping professionals: A hidden public health issue
summary: The 600,000 or so employees in the French housekeeping industry handle products that sometimes contain extremely harsh chemicals.

title: 'Young women are increasingly progressive, while men of the same age are leaning conservative'
summary: Several studies have revealed a potentially dramatic and ubiquitous gap between genders, notes Le Monde journalist Marie Charrel.

title: Russia makes slow but steady advance in Ukraine
summary: New weapons, replenished missile stocks and a more responsive command structure are enabling Russia to make steady territorial gains that are worrying Kyiv and its allies.

title: New York rattled by 4.8 magnitude earthquake
summary: 'The whole house was really shaking,' said one resident, after a rare earthquake hit the Atlantic Coast.

title: Unemployment insurance: French PM Attal defends his reform 'more focused on activity than inactivity'
summary: In an interview with Le Monde, the French Prime Minister ruled out tax hikes on individuals, but did mention taxing companies that 'make profits through inflation' or 'buy back their own shares to boost their share price.'

title: French lawmakers vote to ban 'forever chemicals' except in cooking utensils
summary: Despite opposition from the government, the Assemblée Nationale adopted a bill to ban the use of PFAS chemicals on Thursday. The SEB industrial group, which had expressed concern over the text, welcomed an exemption for non-stick pans.

title: Heatwave risks during the 2024 Olympics: 'Unprepared athletes suffer more heatstroke and medical problems'
summary: Sébastien Racinais heads a group of IOC experts working on climatic effects and athletes' performance. In an interview a few months ahead of the Paris Games, he explains the impact and risks of high temperatures on the body.

title: In Morocco, newborn baby trafficking rekindles debate on abandonments
summary: A revision of the family code is expected in the country, with associations calling for systematic recognition of paternity through DNA testing.

title: French schoolboy dies as Macron warns of teenage violence
summary: A 15-year-old teenager was badly beaten and rushed to hospital on Thursday before dying from his wounds, in the latest incident of school violence in France.

title: McDonald's to buy back Israeli stores after boycott
summary: McDonald's said on April 5 that it would buy back the Golden Arches restaurants from the Israel franchisee Alonyal Limited.

title: Strasbourg terror trial: A heavy sentence for Christmas attack plotter, but still no clear motive
summary: The main defendant was sentenced on Thursday to 30 years' imprisonment for arming the terrorist who killed five bystanders on December 11, 2018.  But the motivations of this non-radicalized man remained elusive.

title: Israeli army uses AI to identify tens of thousands of targets in Gaza
summary: The use of artificial intelligence is not contrary to international law, but the way Israel is using it could amount to a war crime, experts have said.

title: Vingegaard suffered lung damage in Tour of Basque Country crash
summary: The Danish cyclist was diagnosed with a broken collarbone and several broken ribs after a mass crash during the fourth stage of the race in northern Spain.

title: Journalism and Crisis: Join Le Monde in English for a special event in New York!
summary: Le Monde's English edition crosses the Atlantic from April 15-17 for a series of events in New York City, free and open to the public.

title: The rise of gangs in Haiti has enabled them to claim power
summary: The resignation of Prime Minister Ariel Henry has highlighted the growing power of criminal groups terrorizing the country. For a long time they have been financed and controlled by corrupt politicians. Now they are breaking away from their sponsors and trying to impose their own political agenda.

title: Iran pays homage to Guards killed in Syria strike, vows revenge
summary: Iran's supreme leader and the chief of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards have said they would make Israel pay for Monday's air strike.

title: Killer fish in the Seine: A French director battles Netflix over Paris thriller script
summary: A carnivorous fish is devouring swimmers in the Paris seine on the eve of the Olympic Games: This film, according to director Vincent Dietshcy, is one that so closely resembles his own project that he's willing to take Netflix to court.

title: Senegal's new president names 'breakaway' government
summary: Bassirou Diomaye Faye, the country's youngest president, has promised a 'systemic transformation' for the country.

title: Victor Wembanyama, 'one of the loudest voices in the dressing room' of the San Antonio Spurs
summary: Victor Wembanyama's first season in the NBA was a great success on a personal level, and he won over his team-mates at the Texan franchise, who are full of praise for the French basketball player.

title: From villages to dams, a hike along the Dordogne River
summary: Between Corrèze, Cantal and Puy-de-Dôme, a 430-kilometer footpath runs more or less alongside the river, offering moments of woodland tranquility and awe-inspiring views of reservoirs steeped in controversy.

title: Peru's president questioned by prosecutors in 'Rolexgate' probe
summary: Dina Boluarte previously said jewelry was 'fruit of her labor'.

title: 'Football fans are no more steeped in racism and homophobia than the rest of the population'
summary: Like the new campaigns launched by the French Professional Football League, the fight against discrimination in football wavers between voluntarism and ambiguity, says journalist Jérôme Latta in a column.

title: New York, the Native American city: 'This is our ancestral land. It holds their spirits, our stories'
summary: Robbed of their land by the Dutch in the 17th century, the Lenape left the region and traces of their past were erased. As the arrival of the first settlers is about to be celebrated, the Native Americans' descendants seek to perpetuate the memory of their forebears and claim their place in America's national narrative.

title: German parents who travel the world in minivans
summary: As part of a series exploring parenting abroad, this week Le Monde looks at Germany, where every year, thousands of parents take advantage of their parental leave to travel abroad with their children.

title: France and Rwanda's unfinished reconciliation
summary: France's president will not be visiting Kigali to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Tutsi genocide. However, he is expected to post a video to social media on Sunday declaring that 'France, which could have stopped the genocide with its Western and African allies, did not have the will to do so.'

title: Early heat wave takes France above 30°C on Saturday
summary: Such high temperatures are very rare this time of year, according to France's national weather service, as summer is gradually taking over the other seasons.

title: How anger became our driving emotion: 'As a civilization's engine, it's worrying'
summary: From the success of 'rage rooms' to politics and pop culture, latent anger infuses our daily lives. Once considered a mortal sin, fueling this emotion is now popular. But be careful not to overheat.

title: Mexico cuts ties with Ecuador after embassy raid
summary: Ecuador police stormed Mexico's embassy in Quito on Friday to arrest former Ecuadoran vice president Jorge Glas who was taking refuge there.
